title.narrative: Life-saving nutrition screenings and treatment of children with severe and moderate acute malnutrition in the most food insecure municipalities in Cunene, Huíla, Namibe and Bié provinces in Angola

description.narrative: The main objective of this UNICEF project is to improve the quality and coverage of services for the screening, early detection, referral, treatment and prevention of Severe Acute Malnutrition among children 6-59 months in drought-affected provinces of Huila, Cunene, Bié, and Namibe. With this 2,999,851 USD CERF grant, UNICEF will carry out malnutrition active case finding and to provide severe malnutrition treatment to the affected under-five children along with awareness on nutrition good practices to the caretakers. The project will last six months. It will benefit 341,565 persons including 96,000 women and 128,146 girls

owner-org.narrative: UN OCHA Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

organisation.narrative: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

mailing-address.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF), 2 United Nations Plaza (DC2), East 44th street (13th floor), United Nations, New York, USA

description.narrative: Disbursement to CERF Project Life-saving nutrition screenings and treatment of children with severe and moderate acute malnutrition in the most food insecure municipalities in Cunene, Huíla, Namibe and Bié provinces in Angola

title.narrative: RESIDENT / HUMANITARIAN COORDINATOR REPORT ON THE USE OF CERF FUNDS ANGOLA RAPID RESPONSE DROUGHT 2019

condition.narrative: CERF funding is based on an agreed proposal, including specific planned outcomes and outputs.

description.narrative: 245,565 children under five are screened in 28 municipalities in the most drought and food insecurity provinces of Cunene, Huíla, Namibe and Bié and at least 32,912 children aged 6-59 months with SAM admitted for treatment Nutrition - Nutrition
Number of children disaggregated by sex screened in the 23 municipalities in Cunene, Huíla, Bié, and Namibe provinces.
Number of children under 5 years old with moderate acute malnutrition (MAM) referred and treated
Number of children under 5 years old with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) referred and treated
Number of community health providers trained on care for children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) (baseline: 25)
Number of healthcare providers trained on care for children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) (baseline: 30)

96,000 caregivers increase their knowledge on life-saving preventative practices for severe acute malnutrition, health, on improved infant-young child feeding (IYCF) practices, and on good hygiene, water, and sanitation practices.
Number of caregivers of children 0-59 months with access to counselling on early detection of malnutrition signs and positive IYCF, health and hygiene preventative practices (baseline: 5,000)
